title: What is the best alternative rock song of all time? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not so fast. “Alternative” covers a lot of ground. Some of the signposts I caught along the way: 1966—Lou Reed and The Velvet Underground I caught live at The Cellar in Fort Worth. Their history says the band was the Exploding Plastic Inevitable until ’67, but I remember them appearing as VU. Reed had little influence on the rock explosion of the late 60s but seemed to gain in stature and have a lot influence more than a decade later as alternative “proper” caught on. Hard to miss, but I’ll go with Sweet Jane:  1967—I spent every Tuesday night that summer at the Jade Room watching The 13th Floor Elevators with Roky Erickson. It’s hard to argue that a psychedelic band was alternative in the psychedelic era, but more than a dozen years later they enjoyed a rebirth as avatars of alternative. I was even interviewed on KZSU, Stanford’s radio station, because I knew the band and had met Roky after he got out of prison (looking nowhere near as handsome as his younger self). Their big hit at the time  1968—My roommate Sam and I couldn’t get enough of MC5, which I’d call alternative as it was political rock, White Panthers, baby… the sound of the revolution! Their anthem  Those acts I consider proto-alternative. Rockabilly, the music of my grade-school years, is considered alternative by some—not me. But this rockabilly artist definitely had an impact on later alternative:  Real Alternative Punk was a breath of fresh air for me. Rock had got quite insipid, and punk restored its youthful vigor. You name the band, I liked them. The band that stood out most for me was the Circle Jerks, and that had a lot to do with their appearance as the lounge band in Alex Cox’s 1984 punk film Repo Man, a performance quite at odds with their more usual fare, like this:  1994—My oldest son got into Jello Biafra and the Dead Kennedys well after their 70s prime. Still, hard to miss the influence of MC5:  I took the boys a couple of times to see Naoko, Bob and the Ass Baboons of Venus in the alternative category of Japanese operatic screaming. An example:  I’ve always preferred the off-beat to the beat. I’ll take Leningrad Cowboys, Iggy Pop, Patty Smith, Blondie or Weezer any day… White Stripe, Black Keys, Green Day. REM, U2, O.A.R. I like my music innovative and hard-driving. Hope this list alerts you to some of my faves you may not have been aware of.

Since you've probably listened to some big bands already, I’m going to give you two bands that you’ve probably never heard of. They’re both from Japan, and they’re both great in their own ways. Ellegarden is no longer active, but in their years of activity, they released some very solid songs. They’re definitely on the more mainstream side of alternative rock, but they still rock pretty hard. I wouldn't say they were particularly innovative, but from within their comfortable pop punk sound, they made some catchy, loud, and sometimes relatively heavy songs. I haven’t listened to all of their material, but some of my favorites from what I’ve heard include “Fire Cracker,” “Space Sonic,” “Alternative Plans,” “Supernova,” and “Stereoman.”If you prefer something with more of a raw indie sound, I recommend Indigo La End. I’m relatively new to them, so I can’t say how their sound has changed over time. However, from their album Nagisanite, I can confidently tell you that they are a great band. The songs on the album range from energetic to melancholy. The sound is a bit raw and lo-fi, but there’s still plenty of thought and vision put into how the album is crafted. The bass guitar is at least as prominent as each guitar, though all of the instruments have enough focus and are arranged very tightly. The vocalist has the sort of style that might be off-putting at first but is great when you get used to it. Off this album, I would especially recommend “Rakuen,” “Rena Ha Asa Wo Ubattamitaida,” and “Shizuku,” though all of the songs are great.

Some of my favourite alt-rock videos from 2017. Kvelertak - Nattesford  I absolutely love the direction Norwegian heavy metal band Kvelertak have taken recently, with the move away from heavy metal, towards a rock-based sound, with elements of Thin Lizzy and AC/DC thrown in. Wolf Alice - Don’t Delete the Kisses  The latest Wolf Alice album throws back to a 90’s sound, and drops Heathers references along with some really good proggy bits. RtJ - Nobody Speak  Run the Jewels are a hip-hop outfit, but the addition of DJ Shadow here is masterful, and the video is exceptional. Garbage - No Horses  Garbage have always been a great band, and I love that they toured with Blondie recently. This video is chilling. Feist - Century  I think the idea here was to remake Michael Jackson’s Thriller video, with Pulp’s Jarvis Cocker doing the Vincent Price parts, or something. Feist performed this song live with Stephen Colbert doing the voice over. Slowdive - Sugar For The Pill  Slowdive came back with a new album this year after decades away from the shoegaze scene, and it is astonishingly good. They sound as good live as they do on record. Black Angels - Life Song The new Black Angels album is solid from start to finish. This video is not official, but it fits. Kind of a tribute to David Bowie’s Space Oddity.

Why ask for single songs? Better ask for good alternative albums! So, here they are: The entire “Ritual de lo Habitual” album by Jane’s Addiction could be a good starting point.  Then, Public Image Ltd (PiL) to spice things a little.  After that, I would recommend Faith No More - Angel Dust. Great stuff.  EMF - Stigma is a hell of an album, too.  And lets not forget about Primus - Sailing the Seas of Cheese  And it would be a crime to leave Sonic Youth out of this list, so you can listen to Goo.  And the masterful Smashing Pumpkins debut, Gish.

I'm guessing that since you're already interested enough in alt-rock to ask for good recommendations, you already know the essentials like Smells Like Teen Spirit and Seven Nation Army, so I won't waste time on those. If not, then theres two recommendations already. Here's a few lesser known ones that I like and that are considered good though. -”Who You Are” by Pearl Jam -”Soma” and “Cherub Rock” by The Smashing Pumpkins -”Mommy's Little Monster” by Social Distortion -”Adam’s Song” by Blink-182 -”DOA” by Foo Fighters -”Bluebird is Dead” by Electric Light Orchestra -”I Still Haven't Found What I'm Looking For” by U2 -”High and Dry” by Radiohead -”Sex Type Thing” by Stone Temple Pilots -”Apocalypse Please” by Muse -”Nazi Driver” by Soundgarden -”Enemy” by Fozzy Just some ones that I like and that are considered good. Some of those border on alt-metal, but it's the same idea.

Can you recommend some alternative rock songs? Disclaimer: I find “alternative rock” to be an overly broad and exceedingly inclusive term. Pretty much anything vaguely rockish and not overtly mainstream falls into this category. Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds - John Finn’s Wife Drive Like Jehu - New Math Sleater-Kinney - Memorize your Lines Okkervil River - Red Mission of Burma - Fame and Fortune The Feelies - Slow Down Algiers - Blood Sharon Van Etten - Magic Chords

Any list like this, regarding Alternative Rock songs, has to have “Radio Free Europe” on it. It’s a cornerstone of the genre. R.E.M. wasn’t the first band to play what initially was categorized as “College Radio”, music that was hard to pin down as to its genre, but they were the first to hit it really big. Eventually the suits in the music business settled on Alternative Rock. Though “Radio Free Europe” may not be the best song in the genre, there’s really no such thing, it’s a dang good one and an important one.

I mainly like/write this kind of music. Here are some bands I like: Green Day Linkin Park Panic! at the Disco Fall Out Boy tøp MCR Paramore (You’d likely be looking for the “Riot!” and “Brand New Eyes” albums). ROAM (mainly Smile Wide songs, at this time only 2 released, Piranha -the softer one- and I Don’t Think I Live There Anymore -the harder one-) Skillet Nirvana Evanescence And a new one: First And Forever. -only 3 songs at the time I’m typing this, but they’re hella good.- If you also want more metal, I’d suggest “Through the Fire And Flames” by DragonForce, and the song that isn’t even 1 second long, by Napalm Death, “You Suffer”.

That’s a pretty broad request, so I’ll suggest a wide variety spanning the past ~30 years. Jane’s Addiction: Pigs in Zen, Classic Girl, My Cat’s Name is MaceoSmashing Pumpkins: Soma, Galapagos, BodiesNine Inch Nails: Terrible Lie, March of the Pigs, The Great BelowPoe: Angry Johnny, Haunted, HelloPearl Jam: Jeremy, DaughterMarcy Playground: Sex and CandyThe Killers: Smile Like You Mean It, When You Were YoungGarbage: Only Happy When It Rains, You Look So Fine, AmendsMetric: Help I’m Alive, Hustle Rose, The ShadeHole: Miss World, Malibu, DyingMarilyn Manson: Cake and Sodomy, The Speed of PainPorno for Pyros: PetsParamore: Last Hope, Future, PoolSiouxsie and the Banshees: Kiss Them For MeColdplay: Warning Sign, A Rush of Blood to the HeadNirvana: In Bloom, Heart-Shaped BoxAlanis Morissette: You Learn, Front Row, Thank U

"Alternative" is really a debated term. But my pick would be Sonic Youth's "Teen Age Riot".  It undeniably rocks hard, and that's about it.
Many but anything by Bad Religion, Alice in Chains, Jesus and Mary Chain,Garbage, Tool,Sonic Youth, Pixies or Mark Mulcahy spring to mind enjoy.
